Irina is requesting a loan of $1,200 for several purposes. She is planning to purchase a range of office supplies, toner and copier paper. Financial assistance will help Irina secure good maintenance for her copy machines so that she can provide a high quality copying service. It will also help her cover some necessities at home to improve the quality of life for her family. Increased sales and services will generate more profits allowing Irina to save money and eventually buy a facility for her business which has always been her dream.

Ірина – одружена. В неї дорослий син, йому 26 років. Вона доглядає 10-річного хлопчика-сироту з родини алкоголіків. До того ж Ірина ще дбає про хвору жінку похилого віку, в якої не має рідних. Бізнес з продажу канцтоварів та надання послуг копіювання, яким займається Ірина, - єдине джерело доходів для родини. Ірина – дуже комунікабельна. Її ввічливість та дружелюбність забезпечили їй гарну репутацію на ринку. Ірина вміє розпоряджатися власними фінансами. Вона отримала та без жодних проблем виплатила 12 позик в „Надії України”. Позики сприяли поступовому росту бізнесу Ірини. Вона починала з торгівлі канцтоварами за маленьким столиком. Кредитні послуги „Надії України” допомогли їй придбати товари оптом та винайняти склад для зберігання інвентарю. Нещодавно вона придбала два ксерокси та зараз надає копіювальні послуги. Ірина просить про позику в 1 200 доларів через декілька причин. Вона планує придбати різні канцтовари, картриджі та папір для копіювання. Фінансова підтримка допоможе Ірині забезпечити якісну роботу копіювальних машин. До того ж позика допоможе їй придбати необхідні речі для дому, які покращать рівень життя її рідних. Зростання обсягів продажу та розширення сфери надання копіювальних послуг допоможуть Ірині отримати додатковий прибуток, заощадити гроші та врешті решт придбати власну будівлю для свого бізнесу, про яку вона завжди мріяла.

loans.use: To increase turnover capital

loans.name: Vaimaila

texts.en: Vaimaila is 30 years old, and in an effort to support her family, she has started a small flea market stall.  Here she sells nuts, fruits, vegetables and coconut tree fibers.  Most of these items are grown or handmade by her and her husband.  She hopes to expand the products that she can offer the customers in her village, and is thus seeking a loan to purchase additional materials for making handicrafts and growing vegetables.  Vaimaila is passionate about becoming a small business owner and is putting all of her efforts into growing her flea market stall.  She feels that this is the best way for her and her husband to raise the standard of living for her family.

loans.use: Buy raw materials to make/grow goods for her flea market stall

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Expand her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase wood and tools to improve the finish on the furniture he builds

loans.name: Phan

texts.en: Mrs. Phan S. Y., age 27, raises pigs on her land. Her husband, 30, is a farmer who earns $2 per day selling his produce. They have one small child who is too young attend school. In order to grow her business and increase revenue, she would like to request a loan of $250 to purchase additional piglets to raise and sell at the market. Increasing her inventory will meet growing customer demand and allow her to save money for the future. Her husband is pictured in front of her pigsty because she was not available at the time of the photo.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell.

loans.name: P. Herlin

texts.id:
Herlin has been in Bali since 1988. However his meatball business he started in 2004. Every day he prepared his items and also sells it. He sells it by travelling from one village to another using a push cart. Daily income is about Rp75,000 (about Us$8)/day, with nett profit of Rp50,000 (about US$5.25). As head of household, Herlin is responsible for his wife and 1 child. His wife is stay at home mom, and his child sits in 5th grade. Herlin hopes that his business could expand well. Daily expense of Rp20,000 (Us$2.10) and room rent of Rp115,000 (about US$12)/month is one of his calculations.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Herlin sudah sejak tahun 1988 berada di Bali. Sedangkan usaha bakso ini baru dimulainya pada tahun 2004. Setiap hari dia mempersiapkan barang dagangannya sekaligus menjualnya. Dia menjualnya dengan cara berkeliling dari satu kampung ke kampung yang lain menggunakan rombong. Keuntungan yang dia peroleh mencapai Rp 75.000,00/hari dengan keuntungan bersih sebesar Rp 50.000,00. Sebagai kepala keluarga, Herlin bertanggung jawab menghidupi seorang isteri dan satu orang anaknya. Isterinya sebagai ibu rumah tangga, sedangkan anaknya masih duduk di bangku sekolah dasar kelas 5. Herlin berharap usahanya ini dapat berkembang dengan baik. Biaya hidup per hari sebesar Rp 20.000,00 dan biaya sewa kos sebesar Rp 115.000,00/bulan menjadi salah satu pertimbangannya.

loans.use:
To buy a pushcart

Membeli rombong.

loans.name: Vilma Frecia

texts.es:
Mrs. Vilma Frecia is 57 years old and lives in the Salaverry District, in the province of Trujillo, depart of La Libertad. She studied in a technical field but due to personal reasons chose not to follow that path. She has 4 children but none of them depend on her. A while ago she moved to Argentina to work because she had many needs and couldn’t find work here. With the money she saved she opened a small store in her home.

Her mother-in-law invited her to be a member of the communal bank JERID – On the way to Success, and through them obtained her first loan of approximately US $100 which she used with her savings to buy groceries and shelves to display her products.

With this loan of US $350, which she’ll pay back in 4 months, she’ll buy rice, sugar, oil, noodles, eggs and panetones (traditional holiday bread) that she’ll sell during this holiday season.

Mrs. Vilma dreams of returning to Argentina and starting a business there.

Translated from Spanish by Lizella West, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Vilma Frecia tiene 57 años de edad, vive en el Distrito de Salaverry, Provincia de Trujillo, departamento La Libertad. Estudió una carreta técnica pero no la ejerció por motivos personales. Tiene 4 hijos que ya no dependen de ella. Hace un tiempo atrás viajó a Argentina a trabajar porque tenía muchas necesidades y acá no conseguía trabajo, con el dinero que ahorró puso una pequeña bodega en su casa.

Su suegra le invitó a ingresar al Banco Comunal JERID – Camino al Éxito y en este Banco Comunal obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/.300.00, con este dinero completó los ahorros que tenía para comprar abarrotes y andamios para exhibir sus productos.

Con este préstamo de S/.1,000 soles, que cancelará en 4 meses, comprará arroz, azúcar, aceite, fideos, huevos y también panteones que venderá en la campaña navideña.

La señora Vilma sueña con regresa a Argentina y poner allá un negocio.

loans.use: To buy products to sell during the end of the year festivities.

loans.name: Luzmila Elida

texts.es:
Mrs. Luzmila belongs to the Señor de los Milagros de Chavin community bank. She owns a small store selling candy, refreshments and cookies. A year ago she installed a telephone booth from which she sells calling cards, chips, videos and CDs. The business is located in the Chavin de Huantar district of the Huari province in the department of Ancash. With a loan valued at 700.00 sols, to be repaid in four installments, she will purchase calling cards in 10, 20 and 30-sol denominations and 10 mobile phone chips. She will also purchase 10 variety packs of cookies for the store. Luzmila is 38 years old, married and has four children. Her husband is an electrician, and is temporarily employed. The income generated by the business allows her to support her husband and pay for her children’s education.

Translated from Spanish by Joanne Egnatchik, Kiva volunteer

La señora Luzmila pertenece al banco comunal Señor de los Milagros de Chavin. Tiene una pequeña tienda de venta de golosinas, gaseosa y galletas. Hace un año ha colocado un locutorio en el cual vende tarjetas telefónicas, chips, videos y CDs. El negocio está ubicado en el distrito de Chavin de Huantar, provincia de Huari, departamento de Ancash. Con el préstamo de S/. 700.00 nuevos soles, el cual pagará en 4 cuotas, comprará tarjetas telefónicas de S/. 10, 20 y 30 nuevos soles y 10 chips de telefonía móvil. También comprará 10 paquetes de galletas de diferente tipo para la tienda. Luzmila tiene 38 años de edad, es casada y tiene 4 hijos. Su esposo es electricistas, el cual tiene trabajo eventual. El ingreso que genera con el negocio le permite apoyar a su esposo en la educación de sus hijos.

loans.use:
Purchase of phone cards and cookies.

Compra de tarjetas telefónicas y galletas

loans.name: Chu Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Chu Thị L., 54 years old, lives with her three children in Hưng Nguyên, Nghệ An. She is a fourth year member of the TYM Fund. She’s been divorced for many years and singly raised her children. Besides rice farming, she does animal husbandry. Pigs and cows. Her grown up children help their mother’s business. This round of loan she is applying for a 450USD to buy piglets and feed. The current family’s monthly income is 150USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Chu Thị L., 54 tuổi, sống cùng 3 con tại Hưng Nguyên, Nghệ An. Chị là thành viên năm thứ 4 của Quỹ Tình thương. Chị đã ly dị chồng từ nhiều năm trước. Một mình chị L. làm lụng nuôi 3 con. Ngoài việc đồng áng, công việc chính của chị là chăn nuôi lợn, bò. Hiện nay các con chị đã lớn và giúp mẹ được nhiều việc trong gia đình nên chị L. không còn quá vất vả như trước. Vòng vốn này chị L. xin vay 450USD dùng vào việc mua lợn con và thức ăn. Thu nhâp hiện tại của gia đình chị là 150USD/tháng.

loans.use: Buy pigs and food for them

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en: Rukia M. runs a shop selling maize flour, both wholesale and retail. She buys her flour directly from the Azam, Tanzania’s biggest milling company. She also serves as a dealer for the company for other products, such as ice cream, bread, and wheat. She is requesting a loan to purchase more goods to sell and expand the business.

loans.use: Purchase more flour and items to sell

loans.name: Euphrasia's Omega Group

texts.en:
Euphrasia is married woman with 3 children. She and her husband also take care of 1 other child. Euphrasia is a clothes seller, she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 9am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Filipina and Tausi, who have business dealing in shop and clothes sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Agboessi

texts.fr:
Mme. Agboessi S. was born in 1970 in Avétsèdomé in the department of Vo. She now lives in the same village with her family. She is married and the mother of four (04) children, she has a little grocery shop. She has a lot of energy and is enterprising. She gives an enormous hand to her husband with the household finances and the care of the family’s needs. However her business cannot cover all her needs. Thus to revitalize and stabilize her income she is requesting a loan.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva volunteer.

Née en 1970 à Avétsèdomé dans la préfecture de Vo, madame Agboessi S. vit dans le même village avec toute sa famille. Mariée et mère de quatre (04) enfants, elle exerce le petit commerce d’alimentation générale. Elle est très dynamique et entreprenante et apporte un soutien énorme à son mari dans la gestion du foyer et la prise en charge des besoins de la famille. Mais son commerce n’arrive pas à satisfaire ses besoins. Ainsi pour le redynamiser et stabiliser son revenu, elle sollicite ce crédit.

loans.use: Supply and sale of foodstuff

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Le Thi S. joined the TYM Fund since 2004. At first, she used the borrowed money in breeding pigs. After 4 years of membership, she is familiar with the repaying method. She decides to invest in selling birds, for pets and for food. This activity helps improving her family economy. She has 4 children, one of whom is building his own family, one of whom is still going to school, the other two are working and contributing their income. Her husband is a building worker, earning 100 USD/month. This time, she wants to borrow 575 USD to continue her bird-selling activity. Her average income is 250 USD/month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Năm 2004 chị Lê Thi Sáu tham gia vào Quỹ Tình Thương, qua 4 năm tham gia vào Quỹ gia đình chị đã quen dần với việc trả tuần, với những mức vốn ban đầu gia đình chị đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn, các vòng vốn tiếp theo chị đã chuyển hướng kinh doanh buôn bán chim, buôn bán các loại chim cảnh và chim thịt, với hoạt đọng buôn bán này kinh tế gia đình chị ngày một phát triển, chị có 4 người con, 1 con đã xây dựng gia đình, 1 con đang đi học, 2 con đã đi làm và có thu nhập giúp gia đình, chồng chị làm nghề thợ xây thu nhập bình quân 1.500.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 9.000.000đ đầu tư vào buôn bán chim. Thu nhập bình quân 4.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: bird-selling

loans.name: Farkhanda

texts.en:
Farkhanda is married. She is educated woman who has a beauty parlor. She has good experience. She was working in her home before the Taliban regime and her business was very strong. But during the Taliban regime she lost everything and left Afghanistan. When she came back 4 years ago she started her business in Kabul and she is still working in her home.

Farkhanda requested an individual loan to open a shop and acquire some necessary materials to attract more clients and make her business strong and popular as it was in the past.

She is very happy with this loan process. She would like to expand her business in the next few years she wants to thank Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To open a shop and acquire some materials

loans.name: Zafar

texts.en:
Zafar F. is a 30-year-old farmer raising three children with his wife.  Deeply spiritual and physically strong, he has five years of farming experience sowing potatoes, cucumbers, carrots, and tomatoes which he then sells at the local market. Each day he works diligently to make sure that he takes good care of his crops; his meticulous practices enable him to support both his family and his parents.

Zafar is now requesting a loan of $450 for a term of nine months in order to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer. Zafar thanks everyone supporting him and promises to repay the loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Daung

texts.en:
Daung Y., 39, is a farmer, making less than one dollar per day in Kampong Cham province. She is married and has four children, two of whom are students and one of whom is employed. Her husband, Much Soeun, makes approximately US$ 1.60 every day, working as carpenter.

Daung would like a loan from Kiva via Credit, Kiva's local partner, of US$ 150 to purchase seeds (cucumber and other crops) to grow. She told a loan officer that her husband started doing carpentry over five years ago. That business her husband knows from his father. She herself has worked growing rice since before she was married and just now she has started planting crops for extra profit.

Daung Y. continues that farmers make little profit but use a lot of labor. There are no irrigation systems in almost every province and the weather has been difficult for every farmer, too. In the future, she wants to build a better house and she wants her children to study until they get a Bachelor's Degree if possible.

loans.use: To purchase seeds (cucumber and other crops) to grow

loans.name: Jamuna

texts.en:
Mrs. Jamuna K. is a grocery shopkeeper in the town of Balkhu, located in the Kathmandu district of Nepal. Most of the people in this region are engaged in small business. Mrs. K. opened her grocery store seven years ago to pay for her family. She sells different varities of grocery items such as rice, maize, biscuits, and noodles in her shop. In this coming month, the Nepalese celebrate their main festivals of Dashain and Tihar. People buy lots of food for these festivals, so Mrs. K. is requesting a $500 loan to meet the increasing demand of her customers.
Mrs. Jamuna lives in a single family with her husband and two children. Her husband Mr. Bishal K. works in a private office. Both her daughter and son are studying in primary school.

loans.use: to invest in her shop

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela A. O. has been selling women’s used clothing in Rongo, Kenya for eight years, varying her location between two local markets in order to reach more of the community. Twice a month, she takes a bus to Nairobi to purchase additional stock.

Pamela is requesting a loan both to increase her inventory of clothing and allow her to offer more choices to her customers. She wants to increase her revenue so that in the future she can have an even larger stock of clothing to sell.

Pamela and her husband provide for three children of their own as well as two orphans. Three of the children are in school, while the other two have completed their schooling, one now learning the craft of tailoring while the other works in town.

loans.use: To purchase more women's used clothing.

loans.name: Zhanna

texts.en:
Zhanna is married and has one child. She owns a retail business and sells underwear at the central market as well as at two other places. One of them is a department store in the city, another is a seasonal (summer) place at a small resort town in the area. Her gross monthly income is 40,000 UAH, and she has 80,000 UAH invested in the goods at all three places.

Zhanna has great experience in sales: 10 years. She is very entrepreneurial and always looks for new opportunities. Zhanna would like to get a loan of 3,000 UAH to purchase 100 sets of women's underwear. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase 100 sets of wonem's underwear for re-sale

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea E. is 54 years old and a resident of the Kompong Tom Province. She makes a living raising pigs which she sells for slaughter in four months time after raising. She has been raising pigs for about a year and is currently earning around $3 a day. E. is married with eight children, four of whom are single and the other four are married. Two of her children are employed as company staff. Her husband is Kan Moeun, aged 51. He is a local rice trader that purchases rice from farmers to sell by using his truck. E. is applying a loan of $1,000 as capital to allow her to save financially in helping her husband to purchase more rice to store and sell and to repair his truck. (E.'s husband appears in the photograph because she was not available)

loans.use: To purchase rice to store and sell and to repair a truck

loans.name: Phem

texts.en:
T. was born in 1968 and his wife's name is Yon, aged 48. They live together in Siem Reap Province. They make a living both by making Khmer noodles and raising pigs from home for sale. For another income, they are also rice cultivators.

The couple has five children; three of them are married and live away from the family home, and the other two are teenagers and go to school. They also assist their parents in making noodles when they are free.

In order to expand the investments and to reduce the cost of transportation, T. and Yon are asking for a loan to buy a second-hand motorbike, rice, and more piglets to supply their business activities. (Mr. T. is pictured)

loans.use: To buy a second-hand motorbike, rice, and more piglets to supply their business activities.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes M. sells fish which she buys from the fishermen, brings them home for processing and preservation, and then sends them to the market for sale at Bantama in Elmina. Agnes has received junior high school education.  She is married and has 3 children. Her husband is a fisherman. Agnes has been selling fish since 1994. She is responsible for helping to pay the children's school fees and other family expenses. Her loan will be used to increase her capital to buy fish in larger quantities for processing and sale. She hopes to use the new profits to reinvest back into her business and expand her trade in processed fish.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy increase her capital to buy fish in larger quantities for processing and sale.

loans.name: Martha Luz

texts.es:
MARTHA LUZ C. D. MELÉNDEZ, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nuevo Eden” con domicilio en el Jr. Aguaytia N° 441 del distrito D. Yarinacocha, tiene 50 años y 02 hijos.  Su cónyuge se dedica al servicio D. fotografía y fotocopiado.

El primer préstamo D. S/.300.00 Nuevos Soles, compró una impresora y papeles para impresiones. Martha apoya a su esposo en su trabajo D. fotografía.

Con este préstamo D. S/. 1,200. Nuevos Soles, invertirá en la compra D. 2 impresoras, una con escáner y la otra exclusiva para papel fotografía, también se está estoqueando con materiales como hojas, tinta, papel fotografía y todo lo necesario pata su negocio.

Está muy contenta con Manuela Ramos ya que les permite acceder a un crédito rápido y práctico, el cual ayuda en momentos que no se pueD. tener acceso a otro tipo D. financieras.
texts.en:
Martha Luz C. D. M. belongs to the "Nuevo Eden" Communal Bank. She lives in the district of Yarinacocha, is 50 years old, and has two children. Her husband works in the photography and photocopying service. With her first loan of 300 soles, she bought a printer and printing paper. Martha helps her husband in his photography business. She will invest this loan of 1,2000 soles in the purchase of two printers, one with a scanner and the other strictly for photo paper. She is also stocking materials like paper, ink, photo paper and all the necessary items for their business. She is very happy with Manuela Ramos, as it lets her access credit quickly and easily, which supports her when no other type of funding will.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase printers, paper, ink, etc.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is a fishmonger who sells various types of fish at the port in Elmina; she has been in business since 1991. Mary is married with three children and her husband is a security officer. Mary is responsible for helping to pay her children’s school fees as well as the family’s bills.

Mary’s loan will be used to buy more fish with the intention of expanding her business. Mary hopes to use the new profits from her business to buy a plot of land, on which she will eventually build a home.

loans.use: To buy more fish with the intention of expanding her business

loans.name: Marcela

texts.es:
Doña Marcela Q. D. S. esta casada con el señor Paulino S. Ortiz, que trabaja en una empresa D. reciclaje con vehiculo propio, tiene un hijo que aún depenD. económicamente D. ella, doña Marcela tiene dos negocios que atienD. al mismo tiempo dos negocios, su principal que es su tienda D. barrio y su centro D. reciclaje D. botellas D. plástico, vidrio y nylon.
Su negocio principal que es la tienda D. barrio, consiste en la compra y venta D. artículos D. primera necesidad como arroz, fideo, harina, conservas, refrescos, lácteos, etc. El mismo que se encuentra ubicado en su domicilio al igual que su empresa D. reciclaje.
Con el crédito lo que busca con su crédito es surtir mejor su tienda y con esto mejorar sus ingresos y el nivel D. vida D. su familia.
texts.en:
Doña Marcela Q. D. S. is married to Señor Paulino S. Ortiz, who works for a recycling company, driving his own car. The couple have one child, who is still dependent on them. Doña Marcela runs two businesses at once: the main one is her corner store, the other is collecting plastic, glass and nylon waste for recycling. Her store sells basic necessities, such as rice, beans, flour, preserves, drinks, milk, etc. She runs both her store and the recycling business out of her home. With this loan, Doña Marcela will increase the range of products she sells at her store and thus, increase both her income and her family's quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Sara Sultan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Restock a corner store

loans.name: Heang

texts.en: Heang S., 49, is married and lives with four of her children. She sells vegetables, groceries and porridge in the Prey Veng province, typically making US$5 each day, and is supported by her husband who works as construction worker. Heang would like to take out a loan to expand her grocery’s inventory to meet her clients’ demand.

loans.use: To expand her grocery’s inventory.

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en:
Augustina A. is 44 years old, married and mother of five children who are in school. Her husband is a teacher at Dorma primary school. Currently one just completed senior high school and the second is still in junior high school. She has been a food vendor for eight years. She prepares and sells rice and stew and she has also added beans and gari to her menu. This is a delicacy many Ghanaians enjoy every day either as breakfast, lunch, or dinner. She also sells fried rice.

Augustina's business is doing well and she wants to expand her operations to serve more customers. With the loan, she wants to buy more beans, grains, vegetables, rice and assorted meat for her operation. She hopes this loan will help her increase her savings to improve her family's well being. She would be very grateful for your assistance. She belongs to the village bank called Promise.

loans.use: To buy bags of dried maize grains, rice, vegetables, assorted meats, etc

loans.name: Maria Julia

texts.es:
La señora Maria Julia R. D. tiene 23 años, vive en el Asentamiento Humano Victor Raul Haya de la Torre distrito del Porvenir, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudio Secundaria Completa, tiene 1 hija que depende económicamente de ella.
Maria  se dedica al alquiler de peliculas en cinta y DVD, este negocio se inicio hace 3 meses, antes vendía medicina,  su negocio lo desarrolla en su casa.
Su primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco comunal Lideresas en Acciòn  II, lo invirtió en la compra de medicinas.
El crédito de 400 soles, lo invertirá en la compra de peliculas en cinta y DVD para implementar su negocio.
Maria tiene como sueño tener su tienda de peliculas en cintas y DVD mas implementada para crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Sra. Maria Julia R. D., 23, lives in the Peruvian "departamento" of La Libertad. She completed high school. She has 1 daughter in her care. Maria operates a business renting films on tape and DVD. She started the business 3 months ago and, before that, she sold medicines. She operates the business in her house. She invested the first loan, for 300 soles, that she received from her community bank, Lideresas en Accion II [(Women) Leaders in Action II], in medicines. The 400 soles loan will be invested in the purchase of movies on tape and DVD to establish the business. Maria has dreams of owning a more established video store selling movies on tape and DVD and growing as an entrepeneur.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Set up a video rental business.

loans.name: Romy

texts.en:
Romy D. is a 32-year-old farmer and father of three children. He has been a farmer since he was a small child, and started tilling a two-hectare farm that his parents gave him when he married his wife, Merly. His farming business has gone far in helping him pay for his children's tuition, books and other school fees, and provide for the things his family needs.

Looking for a better harvest, Romy is applying for a loan of 15,000 PHP from Kiva partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. He will use the loan to purchase fertilizers, herbicides and other farming supplies.

About CEVI
CEVI continues to help small farmers sustain their livelihoods. CEVI helps small business grow by providing credit, training, savings and insurance cover to all its clients.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, herbicides and other farm supplies

loans.name: Daylen

texts.en:
Daylen V. works on a 1.25-hectare farm. She is a tenant and tills the land that she never owned. Her only wish is that, someday she has a farm to own. She and her husband work so hard everyday to be able to realize that dream. Daylen is now 25 years old. Her future plan is to become successful in her business always. 

Knowing the services of Community Economic Ventures Inc., she wants to avail a loan of Php 7,000. She will use the loan to buy one sack of fertilizer and insecticide. She thinks that by making this move, she will be able to save her farm and have an abundant harvest. 

Now, she continues availing CEVI services. She is provided with not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To buy a sack of fertilizer and insecticide

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a young man who built himself by himself. After finishing high school, he opened small shop in Zboba Village and, with the income from his shop, he was able to finishes his B.A. degree. Afterwards, he managed a school canteen, then he opened a small clothes shop in Jenin, and then, in partnership with a friend, he opened a big shop for brides in which he sell and rents dresses and bridal accessories. Recently he finished his Master's degree and intends to get Ph.D. Ahmad is married and has four children. In the photo, Ahmad appears in his shop.

loans.use: Purchase new inventory for the shop

loans.name: Folo

texts.fr:
Folo K. 27 ans, est micro-entrepreneur basé à la rive gauche du fleuve Congo à Kisangani. Cette ville de la République Démocratique du Congo, qui est située au nord de la ligne de l’Equateur dans la province Orientale, frontalière avec le Soudan et l’Ouganda. C’est une ville qui a souffert de plusieurs guerres surtout celle de 2000 an, qui a amené deux armées étrangères à s’affronter en pleine ville causant ainsi beaucoup de pertes en vies humaines.
Après cette sombre période, Folo a décidé de commencer son activité en vendant de la braise. Au fil de temps et grâce aux revenus accumulés, il est parvenu à ouvrir une boutique qui lui génère aujourd’hui un bénéfice de $20 par semaine. Il est client fidèle qui a déjà reçu 4 fois les crédits de l’Institution de Micro Finance HOPE Kisangani et les a remboursés correctement. Le prochain prêt lui servira à renforcer le stock de la marchandise pour répondre à la demande de ses et accroitre aussi le revenu. Folo travaille durement en épargnant pour réaliser son ambition d’ouvrir un jour un restaurant et d’assurer aussi les études de ses deux enfants âgés de 2 mois et de 3 ans.

loans.use: renforcer le stock de la marchandise pour répondre à la demnade de ses clients

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is a member of the Umoja borrower group in Sakina, Arusha. She is 25 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 4 and 2 years old. She also cares for other 2 dependent.

Flora has owned a food business selling chips for 2 years, she works 8 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Flora`s second loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 250,000 Tsh in order to buy more cooking oil, potatoes and other supplies for her business.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Flora hopes to save more money,pay school fess and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more cooking oil, potatoes

loans.name: Sonia

texts.es:
Sonia tiene 36 años, vive con su esposo y su hijo en la casa de su suegra. Desde su niñez está ha estado ligada a las actividades agrícolas y durante varios años atrás los bajos precios del mercado no compensaron el gran esfuerzo físico y la inversión económica que implica sembrar; otras veces, los cambios climáticos fueron muy drásticos y sus cultivos fracasaron. Ante esta situación optó por buscar cultivos alternativos que mejoraran su producción y compensen su inversión, fue así que empezó a sembrar granos como el trigo, maíz, cebada y quinua, los cuales cosecha y procesa, como en el caso del maíz que lo vende como maíz pelado, dándole así un valor agregado a sus productos, que posteriormente guarda en sacos y los vende en el mercado de abastos de la ciudad más cercana a su comunidad. Sonia se siente ahora muy contenta por esa buena decisión, por lo que planea para el futuro adquirir más terrenos para incrementar su producción de granos.
Esta es la tercera oportunidad en que tiene un préstamo con MFP y está muy deseosa de seguir trabajando por el bienestar común en su banco comunal. El dinero que viene solicitando será destinada a la compra de semilla y a la preparación de sus terrenos de cultivo.
texts.en:
Sonia is 36 years old, and lives with her husband and son in her mother-in-law’s house. She has been connected to agricultural activities since her childhood, but several years ago, low market prices did not meet the great physical effort and economic investment needed to plant. At other times, drastic climatic changes caused her crops to fail. Due to this situation, she chose to look for alternative crops that would improve her production and thus compensate her investment. Therefore, she began to plant grains such as wheat, corn, barley and quinoa, which she harvests and processes, adding value to her products - for example, making corn flour, which she keep in sacks and later sells in the market of the city closest to her community. Sonia feels very happy now about that decision, and she plans to acquire more lands in the future to increase her grain production.

This is the third loan opportunity she has had with MFP and is very eager to continue working for the common good with her communal bank. The money that she is requesting is destined for the purchase of seed and the preparation of her farmlands.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick Clarke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Prepare land and purchase seed

loans.name: Margarita Mavilisa

texts.es: La señora Margarita Mavilisa es casada con el señor Ramón Garcia, el cual es vigilante de un centro comercial desde hace 6 años. Ella inicio su propio negocio desde hace 2 años en la elaboración y venta de tortillas de harina en la cual ya tiene una empleada, y su negocio esta siendo fructífero ya que su clientela esta creciendo porque lleva sus tortillas a las diferentes tienditas de la ciudad. Por tal motivo esta solicitando este crédito para la inversión de su negocio mediante la compra de mercancía para la elaboración de su producto.

loans.use: Inversion en la compra de mercancia para la elaboracion y venta de tortillas de harina

loans.name: Almanso Group

texts.en:
This is Alimany D., Zainab K., Agnes L. and Marie L.. They named their group Almanso Group. They are local entrepreneurs in Magburaka town in northern Sierra Leone seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 each for the first time from Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to improve their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living.

Alimany D. (right) is the leader of this group. Alimany is age twenty-six and he was born in Freetown. He is married to a businesswoman and they have two children – one in class one and the other is not of school-going age. Alimany is a driver who plies between the Makeni and Magburaka highway, and also sells ground-nut/peanuts. He has been in this business for seven years now. Alimany will invest this loan in his ground-nut business.

loans.use: To invest in his ground-nut business.

loans.name: Mario Santiago

texts.es: El señor Mario Santiago  tiene 29 años de edad, es soltero y no tiene hijos. El se dedica al destace de cerdo, además que en su casa de habitación vende también cerdos. El dio inicio a este negocio hace 8 años, por lo que  primeramente él se dedicaba a la venta de carne de cerdo, fue invirtiendo hasta que logro tener su propio negocio sin tener que comprarle a otra persona. Por lo que siempre ha trabajado muy duro para salir adelante. El crédito será invertido en la compra de cinco cerdos que harán mejorar sus ventas e incrementar su capital de trabajo. Su meta es llegar a tener una carnicería que incremente sus ventas y que ayude a mejorar el nivel de vida de el y de su familia en general.
texts.en:
Mario Santiago, 29, is single and does not have children. He butchers pigs. He also sells pigs from his house. He started this business eight years ago. At first he sold pork. He was investing until he was able to have his own business without having to buy from another person. He has always worked very hard in order to get ahead. The loan is to buy five pigs, which will improve his sales and increase his working capital. His goal is to have a butcher shop that will increase his sales and help to improve the general quality of life for him and his family.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy pigs

loans.name: Delia

texts.es:
Delia tiene 34 años, está separada y vive con sus 6 hijos en su casa propia.	Edad, estado civil, miembros de su familia.
Desde de que el padre de sus hijos se marchó, Delia doblegó esfuerzos para mantener a sus hijos, para ello trabaja como jornalera en las chacras desde las 8 de la mañana hasta 5 de la tarde, diariamente. Pero mayormente, ella prefiere tomar contratos completos de chacras de una cuadra donde trabaja varios días, de ese modo sus hijos pequeños la ayudan y para ella se le facilita el trabajo, ganando 260 por chacra para limpieza o para abrir surcos.
A su vez, acaba de sembrar café, pero ha notado que sus hojas no tienen buen aspecto, de abonarlas ahora para el próximo año estaría realizando sus primeras cosechas.

Este es su tercer crédito con MFP, en sus créditos anteriores ha sabido ahorrar diariamente para pagar, sin problemas, todas sus cuotas y se compromete a seguir haciéndolo así. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará fertilizantes químicos para abonar sus plantas de café.
texts.en:
Delia is 34 years old, separated and lives with her six children in her own house. Since the father of her children left, Delia has doubled her efforts to maintain her children, working as a labourer on small farms from 8 in the morning until 5 in the afternoon every day. But on the whole she prefers to take out complete contracts of one paddock farms where she can work over a number of days. By doing this her smaller children can help her and this makes her job easier. She can make 260 soles for every paddock she clears or makes furrows in. At the same time she has just sown coffee plants, but she has noted that the leaves do not look that healthy and she will have to fertilize them now so that they come into their first harvest next year. This is Delia's third loan with MFP. During her previous loans she has been able to save daily to repay all her installments without any problems and she promises to continue doing so. With the loan that she is currently applying for she will purchase chemical fertilizers to nourish her coffee plants.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne Grasso, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en:
Mrs. Chantha K., age 49 (pictured) and her husband, Mr. Ngoun, age 46, have been married since 1979 and have 6 children - 3 sons and 3 daughters. One of the children is married and lives outside the family home, two attend school whilst the other children work in a garment factory. The family lives along National Road Number five about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Chantha operates a farm, growing rice. Her husband is a fisherman and also assists his wife on the farm. Chantha doesn’t have enough capital to maintain her rice farm; therefore she is requesting a loan of $700 to pay for plowing fees and to purchase fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.use: to pay for plowing, fertilizer and pesticide for rice farm

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is 33 years old and married and he has two children who are both in school. He sells "jerry cans" (water containers) and has been in the business for one year. Previously, he was employed as a "casual worker" (a day-laborer or non-salaried worker) by a company. His wife is a farmer. He has been able to plan by using Faulu Kenya. 

George plans to buy 20-liter and 17-liter-sized jerry cans with a loan of Kes.15,000. He hopes to have a stable source of income for him to improve his family's standard of living. He describes himself as hard-working and honest.

loans.use: To buy more water containers to sell

loans.name: Cristina

texts.es:
Nuestra socia Cristina pertenece al banco comunal “COMUZONE” de la Asociación Arariwa, tiene 49 años, es madre soltera y es socia nueva. Cristina tiene una hija llamada Daniela que tiene 17 años. Ellas viven en el departamento del Cusco,  provincia del Cusco. 
 
Cristina tiene una pequeña agencia de turismo “Avventure Danyskat” y también vende ropa para mujeres, varones y niños en especial ropa interior. Ya son varios años que se dedica a la venta de ropa interior y le ha ido muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. Cristina requiere el préstamo para comprar más ropa de la ciudad de Lima como camisas, pijamas y también va comprar sandalias, zapatos y carteras. 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Cristina belongs to the Arariwa Association’s Comuzone Community Bank. She is 49 years old, a single mother, and a new member of the bank. She has a daughter called Daniela who is 17 years old. They live in the department of Cusco, in the province of Cusco. Cristina owns a small tourist agency called “Avventure Danyskat” and also sells clothing for men, women, and children, specialising in underwear. She’s been doing this for several years, and all has gone well thanks to the effort she puts in. Cristina requires a loan to buy more clothing from Lima such as shirts and pyjamas, and she is also going to buy sandals, shoes, and purses. She is grateful for this opportunity to obtain a loan and promises to pay the money back according to the schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy more clothing for her business

loans.name: Ninfa

texts.es:
Ninfa, pertenece al Bancomunal Señor de Acoria, Ninfa es casada, tiene 2 hijos de 12 y 8 años, empezó su negocio de venta de cosméticos gracias a los préstamos que recibe de su bancomunal, ahora también vende comida, prepara platos especiales para eventos, fiestas, reuniones, todo por contrato.
El préstamo que solicita lo utilizará en la compra de una parrilla grande para la preparación de parrilladas, la que tiene ahora es muy pequeña.
El sueño de Ninfa es ser una empresaria exitosa, primero tener un negocio de productos de belleza en una tienda.
texts.en:
Ninfa belongs to the communal bank Señor de Acoria. She is married and has 2 children, 12 and 8. She began her business selling cosmetics thanks to the loan she received from her communal bank. Now she sells food, makes specials dishes for events, parties, and meetings-all by contract. The loan that is asking for she will use to buy a bigger grill to make grilled meat because the one she has now is very small. Ninfa’s dream is to be a successful businesswoman, by first having a business selling beauty products in a store.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Ninfa will use the loan to buy a bigger grill

loans.name: Samnang's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Samang Y. is a married woman who lives in Krang Pou village, Takeo province. She is the leader of a five-member group loan offered by AMK, one of Kiva's field partners. The couple has three children between the ages of three and nine. Two of their children are currently in the local school. 
She and her husband are farmers who own a one-hectare field to grow crops in order to provide for the family's needs. In order to support the condition of the field, Mrs. Samang Y. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Jairo Manuel

texts.es:
Jairo F. Rodríguez, tiene 57 años vive en el barrio Quiroga Central en la ciudad de Bogotá, donde tiene su negocio “Abner A.C. Manufacturas Cuero y Textil”, allí se dedica  al diseño, elaboración  y comercialización de manufacturas en cuero y textiles tales como finos calzados para dama y caballeros, gorras y  elegantes botas. Este es su primer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, solicita $1.200.000  y comprará  materiales en mayor volumen, como cuero y telas especiales para fabricar gorras y calzados, porque quiere aumentar el número de productos que elabora actualmente y obtener con este nuevo recurso económico un crecimiento productivo.
Su meta es lograr en cinco años el liderazgo de su microempresa a nivel nacional y consolidarse por su excelencia.
Su mayor desafío es superar los problemas de la competencia que genera el contrabando de productos chinos y taiwanés, pues al cliente le  sale más  económico y desvía su mercado actual.
Vive en un barrio residencial que tiene sectores eminentemente comerciales, esta combinación favorece su entorno mercadológico pues sus clientes son también familias y propietarios de negocios vecinos
texts.en:
Jario is 57 years old and lives in the “Quiroga Central” in Bogotá, where he has his business, “Abner A.C. Manufacturas Cuero y Textil.” There he dedicates himself to the design, manufacture, and sale of leather and textile items, such as fine shoes for ladies and gentlemen, hats, and elegant boots. This will be his first loan through “Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.” He is requesting $1,200 to buy raw materials, such as leather and cloth, in bulk, in order to manufacture hats and shoes. He wants to increase the number of items that he makes in order to grow his business and improve his income. His goal is to grow his factory to the national level and have it become well known for its quality, all within five years. His greatest desire is to beat the competition he faces from counterfeit items from China and Taiwan, which are cheaper and redirects the demand [for his goods]. He lives in a residential neighborhood which includes some commercial areas. This mix benefits his market, as his customers are also small business owners.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Leather, cloth, and raw materials

loans.name: Wilfredo Rene

texts.es: El señor Wilfredo, es un cliente antiguo de Emprender, en el crédito anterior fue cliente Kiva, ahora repite el monto y el plazo, el Sr. Wilfredo tiene una familia compuesta por la esposa y sus dos hijas en edad escolar, él trabaja de mécanico y la esposa vende lubricantes, estas actividades le proporcionan un ingreso que les permite sustentar su hogar y los gastos que implica su actividad como el alquiler y compra de mercaderia, el cliente es bueno y responsable con sus pagos, además el tiene un ingreso adicional con la renta de su transporte, el que lo trabaja por las noches generalmente, ambos esposos con el trabajo que tienen lograron comprarse una casita por la zona de El Pedregal, con el dinero del credito comprara aceites para autos, el es una persona responsable y trabajadora esta muy agradecido con Emprender y Kiva porla confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Wilfredo is a long-standing Emprender client. He was a Kiva client for his previous loan and he is now repeating both the amount and the term. Wilfredo’s family consists of his wife and two, school-age daughters. He works as an auto mechanic and his wife sells engine lubricants. These activities provide income that allows them to support their household as well as pay business expenses like rental and merchandise purchases. He is a good, responsible client where repayments are concerned. He also has an additional source of income: he leases his vehicle for evening use. The couple managed, thanks to both their work, to buy a small house in the El Pedregal neighborhood. He will use the funds requested to buy auto lubricants. He is a responsible, hard-working man, who is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the trust placed in him by granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies and motor oil.

loans.name: Fati

texts.en:
Fati Mema M. is 37 and married with 3 children.  She owns a business venture, providing clothing alteration & tailoring services to local community members.  Fati Mema has 4 years of experience in this business.  Fati Mema needs a loan of WST $1500 to purchase additional fabrics & materials.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 600 talas or US $250 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Fati Mema joined SPBD.  This is her 2nd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Fati Mema's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics & materials

loans.name: Solidaridad Group

texts.es:
El grupo “SOLIDARIDAD”  esta conformado por 11 socias la Sra. Lucinda es la tesorera del grupo y llevan juntas varios años trabajando cada una en sus negocios, por su parte ella tiene un negocio D. venta D. pollo en un mercado D. la zona, su negocio tiene por nombre “AVICOLA CHARITO” fue su hermana quien le enseño a trabajar en este negocio empezaron juntas pero ahora lo hace ella sola y le va bien, su negocio ha crecido por que ella le da a sus clientes  valores agregados no solo venD. pollo sino también prepara milanesas, cortes especiales y otros pedidos que sus clientes le hacen. Con sus ganancias ha mejorado su  puesto D. trabajo haciendo algunas ampliaciones  para comodidad D. sus clientes, por otro lado su préstamo obtenido en "EDAPROSPO" lo utilizara para invertir en la compra D. huevos y gallina algo que añadirá en su negocio. Para mas adelante ella quisiera comprar el puesto donD. trabaja  por ahora  paga un alquiler mensual pero  esta ahorrando para que en un futuro comprarlo,lleva 10 años en este negocio y su constancia ha hecho que tenga mucho éxito.

*lA Sra. Lucinda es la primera D. las paradas esta con blusa blanca y lentes.
texts.en:
The “SOLIDARIDAD” ("Solidarity") group is maD. up of 11 members. Lucinda is the group's treasurer. The members have worked together for several years, each one pursuing her own business. For Lucinda's part, she has a business selling chicken in a local market. The name of her business is “AVICOLA CHARITO.” It was her sister who taught her how to work in this field; they started out together, but now Lucinda is running the business alone, and it is going very well for her. Her business has grown because she provides her customers with added value; she doesn't only sell chicken, but she also prepares cutlets, special cuts, and other orders that her customers request. With her profits, she has improved her stand, expanding it several times to better accommodate her customers. She will use the loan from "EDAPROSPO" to invest in buying eggs and hens, which she will add to the stock of her business. As time goes on, she would like to buy the stand where she works, since she currently pays monthly rent, but she is saving up to buy the stall in the future. She has operated this business for 10 years, and her perseverance has brought her much success. *In the photo, Lucinda is the first person standing up, with a white blouse and glasses.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying eggs and hens for her poultry business

loans.name: Gemma's Group

texts.en:
Gemma Y. is from the village of Tandul, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is the leader of a seven-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Gemma is 37 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store inside the school campus. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food products inside the elementary school. Gemma has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2008, Gemma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her fifth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Togetherness Group

texts.en:
Seaneah Y. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Togetherness. She is 53 years old, married and has eight children who range from 20 to 38 years old. She did not have the opportunity to go school due to poverty. 

For 22 years, Seaneah has been selling fish at the Fish Market in Sinkor, MonroV., Liberia. She sells in a friendly manner, which keeps customers returning.

She plans to use her 18,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 83,350 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more fish.

Her goal is to grow her business and to continue to support her children so that they can have a better future. She describes herself as a hardworking woman.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Seaneah is holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more fish.

loans.name: Deysi

texts.es:
Deysi tiene un salón de belleza ubicado en la zona 12 de octubre de la ciudad de El Alto, es su principal fuente de ingreso con que cubre la manutención de sus dos pequeños de 10 y 1 años. Vive en la casa de sus padres ubicado en la zona de Alto Llojeta de la ciudad de La Paz.
 
El crédito lo destinara para la compra de herramientas de trabajo (secadora electrica, tintes, cepillos, etc.) para poder equipar su salón de peinados y incrementar sus ingresos económicos.
 
Es el segundo crédito con IMPRO, el buen comportamiento de pago permite la aprobación de otro préstamo para Deysi.
texts.en:
Deysi has a hair salon in the 12 de Octubre area of the city of El Alto. It's her main source of income and helps maintain her two children ages 10 and 1. She lives in here parent's home in the Alto Llojeto area of La Paz. Her loan will be used to purchase work related items (hair dryer, dyes, brushes, etc) to outfit her hair salon and so increase her income. This is her second loan with IMPRO and her good payment history allows approval of a second loan for Deysi.

Translated from Spanish by Solson Scherman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a hair dryer, dyes, brushes and others for her hair salon

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhom N. (pictured above) and her husband, Mr. Sarun Sanh, live in a Phnom Penh suburb, have been married since 1985, and have four children: two sons and two daughters. Three of them are garment factory workers and  the other one attends school. Her husband has been a wooden house builder for more than 15 years.

Sokhom has been selling meals in front of a garment factory for more than 5 years. She also was hired by her villagers to finish ready-made clothes when she is free. She cuts sewing thread. 

Sokhom asked for a Kiva loan one time already. But she does not have transportation and she very often spends a lot of money for traveling costs. It’s difficult for her to manage their income to support their family. So she is requesting her second loan in the amount of US $700 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Han

texts.en: Mrs. N., 51, is married to Va, 52, who is a local farmer. She breeds pigs in a pigpen behind her house, and she helps her husband grow rice. The couple have five children, three of whom are married and have started new homes. The remaining two are single. The coming rainfall is good for growing, and Mrs. N. needs capital for her farm. She is requesting a loan to purchase fertilizers, insecticides, a pump machine, seeds for planting, and to hire laborers to plow the farmland. With any remaining cash from the loan, she will purchase more pigs for her stall. Mrs. N. was not available when the photo taken, so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To purchase products and labor for farm

loans.name: Jelly

texts.en: Jelly B. is from the village of Mozzozzin Norte. She is 28 years old and is married with three school-aged children. Jelly owns and operates a business raising and fattening pigs for sale. She is just starting this business. In 2010, Jelly joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. This loan will be her first from ASKI. Jelly plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Benkadi Iv Group

texts.fr:
Les sept membres du groupe Benkadi IV sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans et en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Ladjibougou, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées par les membres du groupe sont le riz, le petit mil, l’arachide et le haricot. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne et le prêt précédent a été bien remboursé.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, KADIATOU D. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs  1 hectare d’arachide.
La production est vendue au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
KADIATOU compte réaliser un bénéfice de 20.000FCFA environ en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
The seven members of the Benkadi IV group are married women with an average age of 34 and an average of 3 children. For the most part, they live in polygamous families in Ladjibougou, one of the villages in the Dioïla prefecture, in the Koulikoro region, the second administrative region of Mali. They are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better organize their rainy season activities. They grow rice, pearl millet, peanuts, and beans. They are on their second seasonal loan and have repaid their previous loan in full. With this new loan, Kadiatou D. plans on buying fertilizer, small farming equipment, and paying for the labor costs involved in maintaining approximately 1 hectare of peanuts. The harvested goods are sold in Dioïla and Massigui to a client base made up of both men and women. Kadiatou hopes to make a profit of approximately 20,000 francs CFA by the end of the season.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labor, fertilizer, and small farming equipment

loans.name: Georgina

texts.es: La Señora Georgina trabaja como docente en una escuela para adultos, ella es una mujer muy trabajadora, la señora Georgina perdió su casa en un sector donde se inundo hace tiempo y a ella la reubicaron en el sector donde vive actualmente, ella requiere de este préstamo para construir una barda en la parte de un lado de la vivienda, ya que ella teme por su seguridad, por que la señora Georgina trabaja todo el día y su casa se queda sola.
texts.en:
Sra. Georgina works as a teacher at a school for adults and is an extremely hardworking woman. She lost her house since it was located in a flooded area, but has since relocated to another area where she currently lives.

Georgina needs a loan to build a wall to the side of her house because she concerned about her safety. Since she spends all day at work, her house is unoccupied most of the time.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a security wall

loans.name: Mukama Mwesigwa Group B-2-Kampala

texts.en: 26-year-old K. Flore belongs to Mukama Mwesigwa B Group from Kampala. For the last 5 years, she has subsisted on profits from her general merchandise retail shop in Nateete. She began this business with savings from her farming business. She attributes some of her success to her adherence to the golden rules she laid down at the start of her business. Hard work, tenacity and determination have brought favorable changes to her business operations. In a week, this good-humouredly smiling mother of two makes 250,000 shillings. With this loan, she wants to buy more retail goods for her shop. She is looking at buying items like bags of sugar, rice, beans and maize flour.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of sugar, rice, beans and maize flour

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie L. is from the town of Banga. She is 40 years old. Rosemarie is married and has three children, aged 16, 15 and 13. To make a living, Rosemarie plants and harvests rice for sale. She also planted bananas on some part of her land. She sells her harvest to the market.

Rosemarie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosemarie has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Rosemarie is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Margrate

texts.en: Margrate K. is currently in the business of selling beans, onions, and tomatoes, and is requesting a loan to stock more onions and bags of beans to sell. Margrate is 42 years old and is married to a businessman. She has 2 children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: To stock more onions and bags of beans to sell.

loans.name: Florante

texts.en:
Florante P. is from the village of Poblacion 3, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 63 years old. Florante is widowed. To make a living, Florante owns & operates transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating these services. Florante has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Florante joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florante is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to repair her existing vehicle for better service. This will be the first loan taken out by Florante from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Celiamar Homiel

texts.es: Celiamar Homiel R. D. C. D. 32 años D. edad, es una madre D. familia ejemplar la cual se dedica a múltiples actividades para obtener ganancias que beneficien a su familia. Ella vive junto a su esposo y un hijo D. 9 años D. edad, junto a los cuales resiD. en Ilopango. Celiamar, se dedica a la elaboración y venta D. chocolate artesanal, el cual se utiliza para la elaboración D. bebidas, así mismo comercializa huevos, zapatos, productos lácteos lo cuales comercializa D. forma ambulante junto a su esposo. Así mismo hace panes con pollo y almuerzos los fines D. semana en su hogar. Ella se destaca por ser muy trabajadora, y por ser alguien quien cuenta con el enorme deseo D. ser mejor cada día. Celiamar solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda surtir su negocio, y así mismo invertir en la compra D. agendas 2011. Todo esto lo hace con el propósito D. obtener más ganancias y D. esta forma contar con una vida mejor para ella y su familia.
texts.en: 32-year-old Celiamar Homiel R. D. C. is an exemplary mother of her family. She undertakes various activities to make profits that benefit her family. She lives with her husband and 9-year-old child in Ilopango. Celiamar makes and sells artisanal chocolate, which is used to make drinks. She also works as a traveling merchant, selling eggs, shoes and dairy products with her husband. In addition, she makes traditional chicken sandwiches and lunches on the weekend in her home. She stands out as being very hard-working and someone with an enormous desire to be better every day. Celimar is requesting a loan with which she will be able to stock-up her business and also to invest in 2011 planners. She does all this with the aim of earning bigger profits and in this way have a better life for herself and her family.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for making chocolate.

loans.name: Ma. Bella

texts.en:
Ma. Bella P. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 39 years old. Ma. Bella is married and has 5 children. Her eldest child is aged 19 while the youngest is 7. Her children all go to school and it is a challenge for Ma. Bella and her husband to sustain their education. She says it is hard to keep up with the increasing tuition fees every year.

Ma. Bella raises pigs for fattening. She sells pork meat to the market. She also helps her husband plant and harvest rice crops. Ma. Bella hopes for her and her husband's businesses to grow and be able to support their family.

Ma. Bella is planning to buy additional piglets to raise. She applied for a loan of Php 10000 that she will use to purchase piglets, feeds, and farm fertilizers. She is hopeful that this loan will be of great help to her business.

loans.use: To purchase piglets, feeds, and farm fertilizers

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Carmen tiene 62 años de edad, es viuda, y vive con dos de sus diez hijos en el Pueblo Joven Santa Rosa, en los alrededores de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Lleva 33 años vendiendo carne de pollo en el Mercado Modelo de la ciudad de Chiclayo, el mercado principal de la ciudad, por las mañanas y por la tardes vende anticuchos de carne (meat kabob) en la ciudad de Lambayeque, estos negocios ha sustentado a su familia durante todo este tiempo y sigue dando lo mejor de sí para seguir adelante.

Ella compra la carne, tanto de pollo como de vaca, a diversos distribuidores, los que la abastecen periódicamente, ofrece sus productos a sus clientes a un precio razonable, razón por la que ha sabido mantener una fiel clientela.

Carmen desea adquirir carne de pavo para implementar su negocio y poder responder a la demanda que suele aumentar por estas fechas navideñas. Por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles con los cuales piensa lograr su objetivo.

Carmen ya ha trabajado anteriormente con un crédito financiado por el Fondo Kiva a través de Edpyme Alternativa y su producto Capital Semilla. El anterior préstamo le permitió adquirir mas carne para poder ampliar su negocio y gracias a ello su clientela aumentó. Por ello Carmen se encuentra contenta y agradecida con las personas que colaboraron con ella a través del fondo Kiva.
texts.en:
Carmen is 62 years old.  She is a widow and lives with her ten children in the village of Pueblo Joven Santa Rosa, in the suburbs of the city of Chiclayo.

She’s been selling poultry in the Modelo Market in Chiclayo for the past 30 years.  This is the city’s principle market.  She also sells meat kabobs in the mornings and the evenings in the city of Lambayeque.  These businesses have supported her family for all this time and she continues to do her best to get ahead.

She buys the meat, both chicken and beef, from different distributors, who supply her periodically, and she offers her products at reasonable prices.  Because of this, she has loyal customers.

Carmen wants to buy turkey meat to add to her business and meet the customer demand that swells during the Christmas season.  For this reason she has seen fit to request a loan of 1,000 PEN ($375) through Edpyme Alternativa, in order to help meet her goal.

Carmen has had a previous loan that was also funded through Kiva and obtained through Edpyme Alternativa’s seed money.  Her previous loan allowed her to buy more meat so that she could expand her business.  Thanks to this, her customer base also increased.  Carmen is happy and grateful to those who have helped her through Kiva.

loans.use: Turkey

loans.name: Juan Carlos

texts.es: Juan Carlos de 44 años llegò a Barranquilla, procedente de Bucaramanga con sus padres y hermanos y se instalaron en un barrio popular, a la edad de 14 años empezò trabajado como auxiliar de un almacen y al terminar sus estudiso, se vinculò al negocio de su hermana y cuando quiso regresar a su natal ciudad, ya era tarde se habia enamorado de Barranquilla , y esto atrajo su interès de trabajar empleado en el sector comercial, para quedarse  asì  fue que estuvo por 5 años como dependiente y una vez ahorrò , a lo largo del 2007 comprò el negocio de comercializacion de videojuegos ,  que hasta el dia de hoy ha sostenido con mucho esfuerzo disciplina y permanencia . El negocio de Juan Maneja una rentabilidad sobre las ventas del 15% y una utilidad bruta del 24.2% y el sigue soñado con hacer de su negocio una gran empresa para genera muchos empleos y servir a la sociedad colombiana. Su crediKiva  es el primer finaciamiento y con el comprarà modernos videojuegos para surtir su negocio en la època navideña , pues  por tradiciòn Santa Claus trae regalos a los niños en las familias y justamente en esta  temporada  se da el  repunte de sus ventas y esto facilita el èxito de la inversiòn
texts.en:
Juan Carlos, 44 years old, came to Barranquilla from Bucaramanga, along with his parents and siblings.  They settled into a popular neighborhood and at the age of 14, he started working as a helper in a grocery store.  After finishing his studies, he got involved with his sister's business.  By the time he wanted to return to his hometown, it was already too late because he'd fallen in love with Barranquilla.  This is what attracted him to the idea of finding employment in the commercial sector.  To get there, he worked underneath someone else for five years until, at long last, he had saved enough money and bought his own video game sales business in 2007. To this day, he has maintained his business through much effort, discipline, and steadfastness.  Juan's business makes a 15% profit on sales, with a gross profit of 24.2%.  He continues to dream of turning his business into a great company that would employ many people and serve the Colombian society.

This "crediKiva" is his first loan and he will buy new video games with it in order to stock up his store for the Christmas season.  Because the legend of Santa Claus says that he brings Christmas gifts to children, Juan Carlos' sales surge in this season, fueling the success of his investment.

loans.use: to buy new video games in order to stock his business for the Christmas season

loans.name: Cumbe (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Cumbe está conformado por 13 socias quienes son mujeres que laboran en diferentes actividades en su parroquia o en la ciudad, estas actividades les han permitido crecer en la economía de sus hogares y así salir  adelante. Viven en la parroquia Cumbe, esta parroquia es de clima frió en donde la su gente se dedica a la cría de animales y  a la agricultura, en esta parroquia podemos disfrutar de la paz de la naturaleza.

La Señora. María B. vive en la comunidad de San Antonio, es socia del banco comunal Cumbe y este es su segundo crédito. 
Tiene 62 años, es casada y tiene 7 hijos quienes todos son mayores de edad, casados y viven independientes. Vive junto a un nieto quien tiene 11 años de edad  y estudia en la escuela. Con el trabajo de ella y de su esposo han logrado construir su casa propia, su esposo labora como albañil.
Doña María se dedica a compra y venta de pollos pelados, los cría hace un año y los vende en su propia comunidad, también se dedica a la agricultura, pero lo que cultiva es mas para su consumo.
Su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de más pollos para el negocio. Su meta es  tener más animales para la venta.

La Señora. Julia Huylasaca vive en la parroquia de Cumbe, tiene 19 años, vive en unión libre y esta muy feliz ya que tiene 7 meses de embarazo. Su esposo labora como albañil, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven en casa de su mamá.
La Señora. Julia por el momento se encuentra en su casa debido a su embarazo pero antes laboraba en la atención de una tienda.
Este es su primer crédito que realiza en el banco comunal y fue invitada por una amiga, el dinero de su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de pollos para iniciar con este negocio. Su meta es tener una tienda en su casa.
texts.en:
The Cumbe Communal Bank is comprised of 13 members.  They are women who work in different business activities in their parish or in the city.  These activities have allowed them to grow financially in their households and to get ahead.  They live in the Cumbe parish, which has a cold climate.  The people there raise animals and farm.  One can enjoy the tranquility of nature in this parish.

María Buelve lives in the San Antonio community.  She is a member of the Cumbe Communal Bank, and this is her second loan.  She is 62 years old, married, and has seven children.  All of her children are adults, married, and live independently.  She lives with an 11 year old grandchild who attends school.  Through work, she and her husband have managed to build their own house.  Her husband works as a bricklayer.

María buys and sells dressed chickens.  She raises them for a year, and she sells them in her own community.  She also farms, but what she grows is more for her consumption.

She will use her new loan to buy more chickens for the business.  Her goal is to have more animals to sell.

Julia Huylasaca lives in the Cumbe parish.  She is 19 years old, and she is in a common-law marriage.  She is very happy to be seven months pregnant.  Her husband works as a bricklayer.  They do not have their own house, so they live in her mother’s house.

At the moment Julia is in her house due to her pregnancy.  However, she previously worked tending a store.  This is her first loan in the communal bank.  She was invited by a friend.  She will use the loan to buy chickens to start this business.  Her goal is to have a store in her house.

loans.use: To buy chickens

loans.name: Apolinaria

texts.es:
Doña Apolinaria, tiene 61 años de edad, reside en San Francisco Gotera, departamento de Morazán, vive con un nieto de 16 años, un sobrino de 24 y una nieta de 1 año y medio, se dedica a vender productos de primera necesidad, tamales, cuajada y tortillas, este negocio tiene muchos años de existir y es su fuente de ingreso para mantener el hogar en buenas condiciones.
Ella está solicitando actualmente un préstamo para abastecer el negocio comprando arroz, azúcar, aceite, frijoles y demás productos que ofrece a los clientes, con este préstamo pretende mejorar la variedad de alimentos necesarios en cada hogar logrando mantener la preferencia de los que ya forman parte de su clientela.
Sueña con desarrollar el negocio, alcanzar estabilidad económica y estar unida a su familia para alcanzar juntos las metas y sueños a futuro.
texts.en:
Apolinaria, age 61, lives in San Francisco Gotera, in the Morazan department. She lives with a 16-year-old grandson, a niece, age 24, and a granddaughter age 1 and a half. Apolinaria sells basic staples, tamales, curds, and tortillas. She has had this business for many years, and it is her source of income to maintain her home in good condition.
She is requesting a loan to stock her business, buying rice, sugar, oil, beans, and other products that she offers her customers. With this loan, she will improve the variety of food in every household, with a preference for those who are already her customers.
She dreams of developing her business and achieving economic stability, and working with her family to achieve their goals and dreams for the future.

loans.use: the purchase of rice, sugar, oil, beans

loans.name: Rufina

texts.en:
Rufina T. is from the town of Tagbilaran. She is 50 years old. Rufina is married and has 7 children.  Her husband is a fisherman and she sells his catch. She also buys directly from fishermen to get a lower price. She then goes around her community to sell fish. Rufina works hard to improve her business and improve her earnings. 

Rufina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rufina has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Rufina is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets.
